Over half of the people that responded to the first one were men in their late 50s looking for part-time and looking to retire.
And we're looking for young people who are willing to work another 10 years and 20 years in this practice.
Mountain View's recruiting issues are not unique.

A recent Arizona State University study found doctors are most likely to set up shop in the state in which they received their medical degree, and medical schools in states like Arizona and New Mexico don't graduate enough physicians to meet their states' needs.
Economics Professor William Johnson is one of the studies authors.
The scale of medical school enrollment in Arizona has--even with expansion, is going to continue to be much too small to reduce or even supply an adequate number of physicians.
That means Arizona, which grew by 40 percent in the 1990s, must now recruit nine out of every 10 of its doctors from out-of-state medical schools.
The ultimate fear is that doctors will have enormous patient loads and patients will have difficulty getting in to see a physician.
At Mountain View Pediatrics, that's already a concern for doctors such as Alice Berger, who did both her medical school and her residency in Arizona.

There are certainly days that it's very frustrating, like those winter days where it just seems like the clinic is so full and where's no way to see all of the patients and do as good of a job as you feel like you want to.
Fortunately, Berger says those days are still few and far between.

To keep it that way, the University of Arizona's Medical School is expanding its enrollment, and lawmakers have funded the creation of a new medical school campus in Phoenix and more money for in-state medical school scholarships.
But backers of the plans acknowledge these solutions will play out over the long term.
And his date of birth?
And that means in the short run, doctors like Alice Berger will often be greeted by a busy appointment schedule when they get to work.
For DAY TO DAY, I'm Mitch Teich in Flagstaff, Arizona.
